texts.es:
Doña Lilian, de 40 años de edad, reside en Lolotique departamento de San Miguel, vive con su esposo y cuatro hijos de 20, 18, 14 y 3 años de edad, los cuales dependen económicamente.
Doña Lilian administra una tienda hace 12 años, por iniciativa propia, trabajando de lunes a domingo, no tiene un horario de venta pues la tiene en su propia casa, Ella está solicitando un préstamo para invertir en este negocio, comprando: Maíz, arroz, frijol, azúcar, aceite, sopas, verduras, pollo, bebidas entre otros que a diario vende  a sus clientes.
Este préstamo le ayudara a fortalecer el negocio ya que lograra abastecerlo de todo lo necesario en el hogar, ya que son los más demandados por los clientes. Sus aspiraciones es continuar aumentando el negocio, que sus hijos terminen sus estudios para que opten por un futuro más estable.
texts.en:
Doña Lilian is 40 years old and resides in Lolotique in the Department of San Miguel. She lives with her husband and their four children (ages 20, 18, 14, and 3) who are financial dependents.

Doña Lilian has managed a store for twelve years through her own initiative. She works Monday through Sunday, but she does not have a set schedule since she sells out of her home. Lilian is requesting a loan to invest in her business. She will buy corn, rice, sugar, oil, soups, vegetables, chicken, beverages and other items she sells every day to her customers.

This loan will help strengthen her business by allowing her to remain stocked with all types of household necessities that are most requested by her customers. Her aspirations include continuing to increase her business so that her children can finish their studies. She believes this will give them the chance to have a more stable future.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Malaefono

texts.en:
Age:                            45
Marital Status:             Married
Children:                      5 (ages 6 - 21)
Business:                    Planting and harvesting taro for sale
Loan purpose:              To purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise
Weekly profit:               450 Samoan talas (WST)

Overall Social Metric Score:*               1.5 out of 3
Level of Education:                             1.6 out of 3
Level of Total Household Income:        1.5 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1.65 out of 3

U. owns and operates a business venture planting and harvesting taro for sale.  She has 4 years of experience in this business.  U. needs a loan of 2500.00 WST to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 450 WST per week) to improve and/or expand the business.

In 2007, U. joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral.  This is U.'s 6th loan with SPBD. 

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive, and self esteem.  Please join SPBD's lending team on Kiva to receive updates on SPBD.

*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale up to 3--the higher the number, the better off the person.  The metrics are averaged for the "overall social metric score."  For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise

loans.name: Ruhorobero Twimukye Group-Ntungamo

texts.en:
35 year-old Osbert M. is affiliated with Ruhorobero Twimukye Group-Ntungamo. It is now 15 years since he began his food sales business in Ruhorobero Trading center food market. For the most part, he has been selling beans, coffee and millet. These are high-value cash crops at the markets in his district and other areas of Western Uganda.  Most of the crops Osbert sells are harvested from his farming gardens. 
Osbert is happily married with 6 kids, and he says this business generates him shillings 100,000 monthly. He is requesting for this loan to expand his food sales business to other areas in Western Uganda.

loans.use: The expansion of his food sales business to other areas in western Uganda

loans.name: Dulamsuren

texts.en:
Dulamsuren is 37 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in a ger slum district (Mongolian tent dwelling district) of Ulaanbaatar, in their small family house. Her daughter is a student and the young son attends a kindergarten. Her husband is an electrician and works for a construction company. 

In 2004 Dulamsuren completed a certified manicuring and pedicuring course, and two years ago she started renting a small area inside a beauty shop and opened her manicuring business. The area where she operates is well crowded and her business is doing very well. With this loan she is planning to renew her old equipment by buying a new table, chair, nail polisher, a dryer and some colored lacquers.

loans.use: to buy a new table, chair, nail polisher, dryer and some colored lacquers.

loans.name: Furqat

texts.en:
Furqat is a hardworking and active man who is married and has a child. He works in a bakery. His wife helps him and they work hard to feed their child and implement all their conditions of life. He cooks 500 loaves of bread per day. He has six regular customers who resell his bread in the market.  He would like to get a loan of 5000 Somoni for purchasing flour which will allow him to expand his business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy flour.

loans.name: Victor

texts.es: Víctor tiene 51 años de edad, convive con su  pareja y tienen cuatro hijos. Juntos residen en la comunidad de Villa Quintiarina, caserío  del distrito de Kimbiri. Víctor desde muy joven quería tener su propio terreno para cultivar, para así dejar el trabajo de jornalero y trabajar en tierras ajenas. Pero con sus ahorros que acumuló durante años, pudo al fin concretar su sueño, y ahora posee 05 hectáreas en donde cultiva cacao y plátano, productos que tiene mucha demanda, ya que las empresas acopiadoras son quienes más compran sus productos, en especial la de cacao, es así como recibe buen pago por sus sacos de grano cosechado. En temporada de cosecha y limpieza de sus plantaciones, tiene contratar jornaleros, pero en ocasiones recibe la ayuda de sus hijos. Su plan a futuro es demoler su casa de material rustico y construir una nueva casa a base de material noble, para que de esa manera se sientan cómoda toda su familia. Este es su 12avo crédito con MFP, por el cual se compromete a seguir cumpliendo con su cronograma de pagos, además se siente muy a gusto trabajar con su banco comunal. Con el dinero del crédito comprará herramientas para su trabajo como tijeras de poda, serruchos y machetes que le serán de gran utilidad para mejorar su campo de cultivo.
texts.en:
Victor is 51 years old. He lives with his partner and they have four children. Together they live in the community of Villa Quintiarina, Kimbiri village district. 

From a young age Victor wanted to own land to farm, so as to be able to leave his job as laborer working in land owned by others. Thanks to the savings he accumulated over the years he was finally able to fulfill his dream, and he now owns 5 hectares where he grows cocoa and banana. Both products have a high demand and the middlemen are his main buyers, particularly cocoa. That's how he gets a good price for his sacks of harvested grain. 

During  the harvest and when it's time to clean his plantations he has to hire laborers, although occasionally his children help him. His future plan is to demolish his house, built in basic materials, and build a new house in  finer materials so as to make his family more comfortable. 

This is his 12th loan with MFP and he is committed to continuing to fulfill the payment schedule. He also feels very comfortable working with his community bank. With the loan money he will buy tools for his job, such as pruning shears, saws and machetes, that will be of great use to improve his farm.

loans.use: to buy tools such as pruning shears, saws and machetes.

loans.name: Sweetie Pie

texts.en:
Sweetie Pie Layugan is married and 47 years old. She has a retail shop where she sells a variety of products needed by the people in her community. Sweetie Pie has had this business for eight years.

Sweetie Pie is requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP to buy additional products such as soft drinks, canned goods and condiments. Each month, Sweetie Pie earns 4,500 PHP doing this type of work.

In the future, Sweetie Pie hopes that her business will become a grocery store for her to earn more income.

loans.use: to buy additional products such as soft drinks, canned goods and condiments

loans.name: Maïmouna

texts.fr:
Madame Maïmouna est âgée de 42 ans, mariée et mère de 2 enfants.  Elle  vit  dans une famille nucléaire avec son mari et ses enfants  au  quartier Somono de  la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle commença dès son jeune âge à faire le commerce  auprès de sa mère  qui vendait des condiments et des céréales. Après 5 années d’apprentissage, elle commence à évoluer seule en menant elle aussi le commerce de céréales produites localement.
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle a fait   recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 60 mois et après 4 prêts solidaires et 3 prêts individuels tous bien remboursés, elle est à son 4ème prêt individuel. 
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 1 tonne de riz. Elle s’approvisionne à Niono, Siribala et Dougabougou auprès des paysans producteurs. Madame Maïmouna vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. Elle envisage de réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 100 000 FCFA, ce dernier lui permettra de rembourser le prêt et le reste sera réinvestir dans les activités.
texts.en:
Ms. Maïmouna is 42 years old, married, and the mother of two. She lives in a nuclear family with her husband and children in the Somono district of Ségou City (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having attended school due to societal reasons, she started off at an early age working in commerce along side her mother, who used to sell condiments and grains. After five years of apprenticeship, she began to advance on her own in the same commerce in grains, which are produced locally.

Concerned about satisfying her burgeoning customer base, she turned toward the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. She has been associated with it for 60 months. After four solidarity loans and three individual loans, all properly repaid, she is now on her fourth individual loan. She intends to use this loan to buy a tonne of rice. She gets her supplies in Niono, Siribala, and Dougabougou from peasant farmers. 

Accepting cash or credit, she sells to a customer base composed of women and men. She envisions making a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will enable her to repay the loan. The rest of the profits will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy rice

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.es: Marjorie, tiene la edad de 26  años, está casada y vive con sus 4 hijos y su esposo que son su mayor prioridad. Ella con el dinero realizara la compra de los insumos para la asistencia del tiquizque. Ella cuanta con el terreno opta para la explotación de este cultivo y esta ya sembrado. Ella quiere generar las ganancias para seguir adelante con el crecimiento del proyecto y generar la ganancia para salir adelante con el crédito y a su vez para su bienestar familiar  Es el segundo  préstamo que ha  recibido de FUDECOSUR. Ella no había tenido antes otros préstamos en bancos estatales, pero FUDECOSUR le ha brindado el préstamo con mayores facilidades y la tasa de intereses mucho más baja.
texts.en:
Marjorie is 26 years old and married. She lives with her husband and four children, who are her highest priority. Marjorie intends to use the money to buy supplies for growing “tiquisque” (a starchy tuber grown in many tropical regions). She has chosen to grow this crop and the planting has already been completed on her land. Marjorie wants to generate income so that she can continue to expand this project and move forward. With this loan, she will be able to provide for her family’s welfare.

This is the second loan she has received from FUDECOSUR. Marjorie has not had any other loans with the state banks. FUDECOSUR is providing this loan with better terms and a lower interest rate.

loans.use: to purchase farming supplies.

loans.name: José

texts.es:
El señor José tiene 44 años de edad, el está casado con la señora Marina quien tiene 44 años de edad, ambos de la ciudad de Caacupé. Tienen dos hijos, una varón y una niña, ambos ya mayores de edad.
El se define como un hombre muy trabajador y luchador. Posee una despensa en su domicilio. Su despensa comenzó con un pequeño capital y con un crédito obtenido de la fundación paraguaya y acompañado del buen trato con sus clientes  el negocio va creciendo de forma gradual.   
Solicita el crédito para la compra al por mayor en mercaderías de primera necesidad para satisfacer la demanda de la comunidad y por ende aumentar el ingreso a su unidad familiar. Ve en el crédito una gran oportunidad para su progreso.
texts.en:
José, 44, is married to Marina, 44.  They are both from the city of Caacupé.  They have two children, a boy and a girl, both adults now.

He defines himself as a very hard working, tenacious man.  He has a home based grocery store.  His store started out with little capital.  With a loan from Fundación Paraguaya that was accompanied with good customer service, the business has been gradually growing.

He asks for the loan to buy basic need items at wholesale to meet demand in the community and thus increase his family’s income.  He sees the loan as a great opportunity for progress.

loans.use: to buy stock items at wholesale for his store.

loans.name: Camposeco Group

texts.es:
El señor Juan es casada, tiene 54 años D. edad, se dedica a la confección D. prendas o sastrería,  tuvo la oportunidad D.  estudiar seis años en educación primaria, tiene 8 hijos 6 D. los cuales están estudiando, inició este trabajo siendo empleado para otro negocio, y hasta el momento lleva 10 años D. experiencia, cuenta con el apoyo D. su esposa quien se dedica a los oficios domésticos.

DeciD. organizar un grupo para poder solicitar un préstamo que le servirá para la compra D. materia prima para la confección, va a comprar telas D.  diferentes clases y colores, sierres, botones e hilo. Las demás integrantes se dedican a la crianza D. animales, y a la confección D. pantalones.
texts.en:
Juan is 54 years old and married. His work is making garments and working as a tailor. He had the opportunity to go to school for six years of primary education. He has 8 children, 6 of whom are currently in school. He started this work when he was employed by another business, and now he has 10 years of experience. He has the support of his wife, who dedicates herself to domestic duties. 

He decided to organize a group so that he could request a loan that would allow him to buy materials to create his products. He will buy fabrics of diifferent kinds and colors, zippers, buttons and thread. The other group members work raising animals and making pants.

loans.use: to buy fabrics, thread and other items.

loans.name: Lara

texts.en:
Lara is 44 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 2 children. 
Lara has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan of PHP 28,000 to buy canned goods, beverages & snacks.
Lara has been a member of HSPFI since 2004. In the future, Lara hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, beverages & snacks

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en: Ruby works hard to support her family. She is married and has a electronic repair business in the Philippines, which she has run for 20 years. Ruby has requested a PHP 19500 loan through NWTF to purchase tools and equipment for her electronic repair business. She would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase tools and equipment for her electronic repair business

loans.name: Fast Moving Group

texts.en:
Isatu is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Isatu was born in one of the several villages in Sanda. She is 35 years old. Isatu is a widow with 2 children who attend secondary school. For 10 years, Isatu has been selling cooked rice with sauce. 

This is not the first loan that Isatu and her group members have received from SMT and Kiva lenders. Previous loans have created significant impact in the lives of these borrowers. 

However, with the help of this loan, they will be able to further expand their respective businesses, make more sales and further improve their living conditions. Isatu is going to use her share of the loan to buy rice, palm-oil, groundnuts, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), etc. in order to cook a larger quantity of rice and sauce to sell.

loans.use: to buy supplies in order to cook a larger quantity of rice and sauce to sell.

loans.name: Saidbi

texts.ru: Саидби проживает в районе Хамадони. Ей 54 года. Замужем. Имеет 6 детей. Образование у нее среднее. Она занимается торговлей детской одежды. Этим видом деятельности занимается 15 лет. Кредит берет для покупки костюмчиков для новорожденных.
texts.en: Saidbi lives in the Hamadoni district.  She is 54 years old, married and has six children.  She has a secondary education.  Saidbi is involved in sales of children's clothing and has been in this business for 15 years.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of suits for newborns.

loans.use: to purchase suits for newborns

loans.name: Ihssan

texts.en: Ihssan is 21 years old and single. He lives with four family members in Iraq. Ihssan has owned a food store since 2008 selling soft drinks, juices, cheese and dairy products. He has a deep understanding of local consumer needs. His store is situated in a crowded area so there are a good number of customers passing by. He is requesting loan of $3,000 to renovate and fix his store’s ceiling, floors and walls. He is aiming to gain more profits so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To renovate and fix his store’s ceiling, floors and walls.

loans.name: Keila Maria

texts.es:
La señora Keila Maria tiene 31 años de edad, es madre de tres hijos y vive con su esposo, quien se dedica a la fabricacion de ladrillos, Keila se dedica a la venta de productos de consumo diario, todos los días se levanta temprano para abrir su negocio y atender a sus clientes, los cuales le visitan muy temprano todas las mañanas, Keila tiene dos años de dedicarse a este tipo de actividad, nos comento que le va bien.
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de abarroteria para surtir su negocio y a si tener mejores utilidades y mejorar las condiciónes de vida de su familia. 

Su meta es mejorar su vivienda.
texts.en:
Mrs. Keila Maria, 31, is married, has three children and lives with her husband who makes bricks.  Keila has a grocery store which she opens early to attend to customers who visit her every morning.  Keila has been in business for two years and says it is going well.  She plans to use the loan to buy groceries to stock the business and improve her profits so she can give her family a better lifestyle.

Her goal is to carry out home improvements.

loans.use: To buy beans, tortillas, lard, oil, eggs, flour, bread, coffee, batteries, candles, instant soups, pastry, softdrinks, soap, sweets and balls.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan is married and has seven children, six of whom attend school while one is not yet old enough to go. She owns a house that has electricity and piped-in water, and her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. For the past 15 years, she has made a living running a beauty salon. Most of her customers are neighbors and passersby. Susan also owns rental properties, which supplement the income she earns in her shop. Her major challenge is that the number of customers she serves varies by season. Her goal for the future is to open a hair-dressing school. She is applying for a loan for Kshs 80,000 to buy equipment such as a hair dryer, and recently joined Yehu as a way to access loans that will allow her to boost her business.

loans.use: to buy equipment for a beauty salon.

loans.name: C1921 Umucyo Group

texts.en:
Claire is 32 years old and she is single. She owns a business selling second hand clothes in the market. She is the leader of this group, which is called "UMUCYO", in the local language which, in English, means "LIGHT" (She is the second person on the right side in the photo). Claire has been in this business for about three years. 

Claire and her team have requested a loan from Kiva lenders, via Vision Finance Company, in order to increase their clothes business to sell. Claire and her team will reinvest their profits into their businesses and save for their future.

loans.use: to purchase more second hand clothes for resale.

loans.name: Nueva Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El comité “Nueva Esperanza” tiene más de 2 años de formación y trabajo con la Fundación Paraguaya. Ellas se unieron con el anhelo de  un futuro mejor para sus hijos es por eso que se esfuerzan el doble para facilitarles los materiales para su desarrollo y formación. 
Una de ellas es la señora Cinthia, ella se dedica a la venta de comestibles, comenta que sus alimentos se venden mucho, pues tiene muy buenas manos para la cocina. Gracias a este trabajo ella ha logrado salir  adelante y ayudar  a su familia.
Ella solicita la ayuda de la fundación para la compra de harina, huevos, sal, jamón, queso, los cuales son ingredientes esenciales para los alimentos que prepara.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Nueva Esperanza" has been operating for over two years, working through the Fundación Paraguaya.  The members got together with a desire to provide their children with a better future, working extra hard to provide them with everything they need for their development and training.

One of the members, Mrs. Cinthia, sells food and says her products are popular because she has a knack for cooking.  Thanks to her work she has been able to help her family get ahead.

She is requesting a loan through the foundation to buy flour, eggs, salt, ham, and cheese which are the essential ingredients for the food she prepares.

loans.use: To buy flour, eggs, salt, ham, cheese and other items.

loans.name: Maria Aracely

texts.es:
María, vive con su esposo y dos hijos, es casada vendedora de pollos y vendedora de tamales, estos negocio los comenzó gracias a su propia iniciativa contando con el apoyo de su conyugue, tiene experiencia en ambos negocios y no cuenta con un horario establecido para la venta ya que lo hace de la forma ambulante.
Ella está solicitando un préstamo para la compra de verduras, maiz, condimentos, entre otras cosas para la elaboración de los tamales y para la compra de pollos para engorde, esta compra le permitirá ampliar la granja y atender mejor a la clientela
Su mayor sueño es tener un negocio más grande y vivir feliz con su familia.
texts.en:
María lives with her husband and 2 children. She is married and sells tamales and chickens. She started these businesses on her own initiative with the support of her husband. She has experience with both businesses and has no fixed schedule for sales as she works as a street vendor. 

She is asking for a loan to buy vegetables, corn, seasonings among other things needed to make the tamales and also to buy chickens for fattening. This purchase will allow her to enlarge the farm and better serve her customers.

Her biggest dream is to have a bigger business and live happily with her family.

loans.use: to buy corn, vegetables, seasonings to make tamales and chickens for the farm.

loans.name: Wariti Group

texts.fr:
Justine est présidente du groupe de crédit  wariti, cliente de l’IMF Hekima au 6e cycle, veuve, âgée de 38 ans, mère de six enfants qui vont tous à l’école mais un parmi les six souffre d’un handicap physique. . 
Elle a commencé son petit commerce en 2006 lors de la mort de son mari.  Elle vend des chaises plastiques et le jus de marque TAKENGO qu’on produit localement.    
Elle souhaite obtenir plus des crédits pour accroitre son chiffre d’affaire et  construire une maison en matériaux durable pour sa famille. 
Le groupe WARITI est composé de 19 membres.
texts.en:
Justine is the leader of Wariti Group, which counts 19 members. She's 38 years old, a widow, and the mother of six school-attending children. One of them suffers from a physical disability. 

With her group, Justine is seeking his sixth loan from Kiva's partner, MFI Hekima. She started her small business in 2006 when her husband died. She sells plastic chairs and TAKENGO, a locally made juice brand.

She would like a new loan to bolster her revenue and build a house out of durable materials for his family.

loans.use: to buy plastic chairs and boxes of TAKENGO (locally made juice)

loans.name: Tum

texts.en:
Tum (in the photo), age 26, is single and lives with her parents and brothers and sisters in a village approximately twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Her parents are rice farmers.

Tum is a garment worker. She is applying for a loan of $1,000 to assist in her parents’ rice farming business by buying rice seed and a pipe and water pumping machine.

loans.use: To assist in her parents’ rice farming business by buying rice seed and a pipe and water pumping machine.

loans.name: Lailatul

texts.en:
Lailatul is a 42-year-old widow who is living with three children, namely: Rifky, 12; Rebecca, 11 and Rizal, 8; they are at elementary school. Lailatul runs a beauty salon business. From the business Lailatul is able to finance her family’s life and the education fees of her children.

Lailatul has been involved in the business since 2007. Prior to running the business, Lailatul attended beauty training, sponsored by the local government. She initiated the business by using her own savings. In this business Lailatul provides hair cuts, cream baths and facials. She offers the services at a reasonable price so the customers like to come to her beauty salon. 

Lailatul needs more capital to improve her business; therefore she is requesting a loan from TLM amounting to IDR 5,000,000 to add more beauty care treatments such as waxing and hair straightening cream. She also wants to buy more products such as curly cream, shampoo, conditioner, hair coloring cream, etc. She is hoping that TLM will approve her loan application soon.

loans.use: to purchase more products such as curly cream, shampoo, conditioner, hair coloring cream, etc.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is a 30-year-old married woman with one child who is not yet in school. She has had a business of selling food items in Kator, South Sudan, for four years.

Flora is requesting this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase bread and tomatoes. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase bread and tomatoes for sale.

loans.name: Tien

texts.en:
Tien, a 65-year-old married man, lives in Ho Chi Minh City. He has 8 children. He and his wife run a clothing shop at their house. They started this business ten years ago. 

Tien requires a loan to expand his business by purchasing fabrics and good quality materials to increase his production of clothes. This will enable him to offer a better range of clothes to his customers. He hopes his business will run smoothly and he can earn additional income to support his family.

loans.use: To purchase fabric and good quality materials to increase his production of clothes.

loans.name: Keum Srait

texts.en:
Keum Srait is 31 years old. She is married and resides with a daughter in Kratie Province, Cambodia. She has been selling clothes for more than two years, earning approximately $10 per day. Her husband (who joined her in the picture) sells water around his village. He earns about $9 each day.

In order to improve her family’s finances, Keum Srait is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase more fashionable clothes to resell. By doing so, she will be able to make more profit to financially support the family. In the future, she would like to expand her business and send her daughter to a good school. Moreover, she hopes to build a new house as soon as possible.

loans.use: to purchase more fashionable clothes to resell

loans.name: Sarin's Group

texts.en: Sarin’s group live in a rural village in Kompong Thom province in Cambodia. Sarin makes a living cultivating rice to support her family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. Having a water filter at home will help each of these women and man to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Famil

texts.en:
Famil is a teacher of education based on work in the secondary school and he is engaged in servise and production. In the beginning of his business he needed in  boring mill. It was a problem for him in order to improve his business.
29-year Famil is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-ocupied territory of  Azerbaijan Kalbajar.This single man settled in Absheron region Binegedi shosse 3.
Having borrowed the loan amount of $400 from Komak Credit Union he solved his problem. At last he bought a boring mill.
The second time he borrowed $800 and bought additional materials: non-ferrous metals and ferrous metals.
Now he wants to buy the lathe.He is very optimistic about the future of his business.

loans.use: To buy lathe

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Elizabeth Wakonyo intends to buy bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Marguerite

texts.en: Marguerite has been active in business since 2003. She runs a boutique and sells beverages. Her business has prospered since she joined Hope DRC (a microfinance program) in 2004. Marguerite is requesting a loan of $1000 in order to diversify her business by adding fresh foods. This business has helped her to support her family. She is married and has seven children.

loans.use: To diversify her business by adding fresh foods

loans.name: Sofía

texts.es:
Sofía is single and has two children who are studying. She has had to put great effort to carry her children forward on her own, and to obtain the resources her family needs, she started her own business fifteen years ago by selling novelties. She has set her heart on improving her business and has made it grow little by little. Today she has three business areas: she sells groceries, stationary products, novelties and makes traditional costumes. It has not been easy for Sofía to carry all this responsibility, but the well-being of her children is her best reward.

Sofía needs a $ 650 loan which she will use by purchasing seasonal groceries in order to increase the variety of products that she offers to improve service quality. She hopes to return this amount in 6 months. It contributes to this business’ growth and to the well-being of this family. They are very grateful for your support.

Translated into English by Patricia Yanez, Kiva Volunteer.

Sofía es soltera y tiene dos hijos que están estudiando, ha tenido que esforzarse mucho para sacar adelante a sus hijos ella sola y para obtener los recursos que necesita su familia inició su propio negocio hace quince años vendiendo novedades, ha puesto todo su empeño en mejora su negocio y poco a poco lo ha hecho crecer, ahora ya tiene tres negocios, donde vende abarrotes, papelería, novedades y también elabora trajes típicos. No ha sido fácil para Sofía tener tanta responsabilidad pero el bienestar de sus hijos es su mejor recompensa.

Ahora Sofía necesita de un préstamo de $ 650 dólares que utilizará en la compra de mercancía de esta temporada para incrementar la variedad de productos que ofrece y mejorar la calidad de su servicio, ella espera regresar esta cantidad en 6 meses. Contribuye al crecimiento de este negocio y al bienestar de esta familia, ellos agradecen mucho tu apoyo.

loans.use: Purchase of Merchandise

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Dona Marcelina is mother to four children, but only her 13 year old daughter remains her dependent. Some time ago, when her children were still of school age, she opened her small store selling staples and sundries in her community. For a long time, her business was not very successful, but now, thanks to her young daughter's assistance, her business is one of the most frequented in the area. Her daughter's contribution has been efficient, sensible and right on target. Response from her clients has been so great that it has been hard to keep up with demand, requiring that they both work the store together at times in order to be able to serve all customers.

To take advantage of this phenomenal opportunity, Marcelina would like to expand her inventory so that each of her clients is able to find everything he needs in her store. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $325, to be repaid over 4 months. Let's help Marcelina make her dream a reality so that in turn, she can help her young daughter realize her own dream of studying fashion design and haute couture.

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Marcelina es madre de 4 hijos y actualmente sólo está a cargo del cuidado de la más pequeña que tiene 13 años, hace tiempo cuando la mayoría de sus hijos se encontraban en etapa escolar, decidió aperturar una tienda para ofrecer artículos de primera necesidad a su comunidad. Durante mucho tiempo este negocio no fue uno de los más satisfactorios pero ahora gracias a la contribución de su hija menor este pequeño espacio de servicios se ha convertido en una de las tiendas más visitadas de la zona.La contribución de su hija a sido muy eficiente y atinada y aún más la percepción de sus clientes; ahora casi es imposible darse abasto y hasta necesitan en determinado horario estar juntas para satisfacer todos los pedidos.A consecuencia de este fenómeno es que Marcelina desea ampliar su stock de productos a fin de que cada uno de sus clientes pueda encontrar en este lugar todas las cosas que requieran y para cumplir este objetivo ella solicita un préstamo de 325 dólares con el compromiso de retornarlos en un período de 4 meses. Hagamos que el sueño de Marcelina se convierta en realidad en poco tiempo para que a su vez ella pueda cumplirle el sueño de estudiar alta costura a su pequeña hija.

loans.use: To purchase more and better quality products to meet high demand

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samue K.  is a teacher at Mpererwe High School. But he also saw a need for the students to be able to buy used books. So he opened a social center where he sells school books. He has operated it successfully for the past one and half years.
 
Samuel is new to his lending group and plans to use his first loan to buy a printer and more used books for his students to purchase.  Samuel is 23, single, has one child and cares for 2 orphans. He dreams of one day opening his own school for secondary and advanced education. This is a very important need for only recently has the government of Uganda started paying for education past primary school  or 14 years of age.

loans.use: Samuel plans to use his loan to buy a printer and more used books for his students to buy.

loans.name: Nasr El Dine

texts.en: Nasr El Dine owns a grocery store in the region of Saida in South Lebanon. He is a very honest and trustworthy man.  He is 60 years old and lives with his wife and child. Nasr El Dine needs to buy merchandise for his shop in order to generate enough revenue to be able to fix the door to his house and to refurbish the couches in his home. This is the second time Nasr El Dine is asking for a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: to buy merchandise

loans.name: I Nengah Widana

texts.id:
Nengah Widana lives in a village called Manistutu on West of Bali. The village is located up on the mountain which makes it difficult to get water for irrigation and household necessities. The villagers are only counting on a small river which provides enough amount of water only in the rainy season. Facing such problem, I Nengah Widana cannot grow crops or cultivate the field maximally. He plants his field with corn. Having shortage in fertilizer and good quality seeds, he often gets low quality yield from his field. With the loan, he plans to buy fertilizer and good quality seeds so that his field can yield maximum produce.

Translated from Indonesian by Iman Persada, Kiva Volunteer.

I Nengah Widana tinggal didesa Manistutu, Bali Barat. Lokasi desa ini berada di lereng gunung, sehingga untuk pengairan, baik untuk perkebunan atau untuk kepentingan rumah tangga cukup sulit untuk didapat. Pengairan hanya mengandalkan sungai kecil yang mengalir didesanya yang airnya akan cukup apabila datang musim hujan. Karena air yang sulit didapat, I Nengah Widana tidak bisa bercocok tanam atau mengolah persawahan. I Nengah Widana menanami kebunnya dengan pohon jagung.

Namun karena kurangnya pupuk dan bibit yang berkwalitas, I Nengah Widana seringkali tidak mendapat hasil yang maksimal dari kebunnya. Dengan pinjaman yang didapatnya, I Nengah Widana berencana untuk membeli pupuk dan bibit jagung berkwalitas sehingga kebunnya bisa mendapatkan hasil yang maksimal.

loans.use: To buy good quality corn seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in more merchandise for the store

loans.name: Rauf

texts.en: Rauf is 24 years old, and lives in Khachmaz.  He would like a loan of $950 to further his business of selling foodstuffs and supplying produce to his village.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs

loans.name: Lucy

texts.es:
Lucy is a hard-working and dedicated woman. Her wishes to offer exclusive knitwear and to dress the beautiful mothers of her city well led her to establish a small shop for selling clothing and footwear where she personally accessorizes each person who visits her each day. Thanks to her efforts and good taste her gains and wishes have not been made to wait. She now plans to expand and start a chain of stores with the name that gained popularity in her community.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva volunteer.

Lucy, es una mujer muy laboriosa y dedicada, sus deseos por ofrecer prendas exclusivas y vestir bien a las bellas madres de familia de su ciudad la condujeron a instalar un pequeño espacio de ventas de prendas de vestir y calzado en el que asesora personalmente a cada una de las personas que la visitan a diario.Gracias a su desempeño y buen gusto las ganacias y deseos de mejorar no se han hecho esperar y ahora tiene planeado expandirse y constituir una cadena de tiendas con el nombre que le dio popularidad dentro de su comunidad.

loans.use: Capital to start her entrepreneurial dream.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhoeun Mom and her husband, Mr. Sarin Phoung, were married in 1984 and have four children; one son and three daughters. One of her daughters is married and lives in the family home, two children are in school, and the youngest one stays at home. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Mom has been a weaver for over ten years, but now she is transferring her loom to her daughter to continue her business.

Mr. Sarin has been a mason for five years. It’s a skill he learns from his neighbor. Mrs. Mom is requesting a loan of US$500 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Silivia

texts.en:
Silivia N., 50, is married with 5 children. She has many years of experience in producing and selling taro and bananas. She and her husband work the plantation and sell to the villagers 3 days per week and also at the market during peak season. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (about US $104).

SPBD loans are Silivia’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to purchase equipment (bushknife ,shovel ,axe ,wheelbarrow ,spade) as well as pesticides and other agricultural chemicals.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for a taro and banana plantation

loans.name: Kunthea

texts.en:
Mrs. Kunthea T., 38, and her husband, Mr. Lonh Sum, 47, who live in a small village across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers north of Phnom Penh, have been married for 20 years and have five daughters. Two of them are in school and two others are weavers.

Kunthea has been a silk weaver for 10 years, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who T. resells them in Phnom Penh. Lonh has been a wooden house builder for 30 years. Now Kunthea is requesting a loan of $150 to purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.name: Put

texts.en:
Put K., 51, lives in Dangkao with her husband, Soa Choeun, and their three children.

Put K. works as a seamstress out of her home and typically makes US$0.50 each day. Her husband works on a farm, growing rice and other vegetables, generating US$1 in income each day. The family is also supported through the employment of their three daughters, who all work in the local garment factories and each make US$3 per day.

Put K. has asked for a loan of US$800 to purchase more materials for her business and also to repair her home. She believes this loan is a valuable investment for her family, and will allow her to improve her family's quality of life and standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase pieces of cloth and repair home

loans.name: Spomenka

texts.en:
Spomenka is a 43 year old woman from the town of Doboj.  She is married and has one daughter.  Her husband has a full time job and earns a monthly salary of 450 KM.  They grow and sell vegetables and earn 200 KM monthly.

This is Spomenka's first loan from WWI and it is for 800 KM ($600).  She already owns some chickens and will use the loan to purchase more, which she will sell during the winter and thus expand their agriculture business.

loans.use: To buy more chickens

loans.name: Loy's Group

texts.en:
Loy M. is a member of the Abateesa women's group in Kabowa. She has been a member of her lending group since its inception and is happy that she has achieved what she has today as a result of borrowing.

Loy is a poultry farmer with both broiler and layer chickens, which she keeps in her home. She has 500 chickens, most of which are broilers because they mature in only two months and hence fetch money faster. Broilers take five months to mature before starting to lay eggs.

Her dream is to increase the number of chicks to over 1000 and then she will be all smiles. She will use this loan from Kiva to buy chicken mash and feeds, as she has used previous loans to do.

loans.use: To buy chicken feed and mash for her poultry farm.

loans.name: Divino Niño Jesus Group

texts.es:
El Grupo denominado Divino Niño Jesús, se conformó en fecha 03 de setiembre de 2008, gracias a promociones hechas por la asesora en la zona, quien comentó con la Sra. Norma E.,(actual Directora General del grupo) del programa de Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras. La misma se mostró muy interesada por dicho programa y logró juntar a 17 mujeres.

Cada una de estas señoras posee una actividad específica, las cuales detallamos a continuación:

1) Norma E.. Venta de comidas.

2) Librada Gómez. Despensa.

3) Francisca A.. Despensa.

4) Liliana M.. Venta de bebidas.

5) Lucia G.. Venta de ropas artesanales.

6) Rosa Samudio. Venta de verduras.

7) Ana D.. Venta de bijouterie y lencerías.

8) Reina S.. Venta de productos de limpieza.

9) Elena González. Venta de bebidas.

10) Aurora C.. Despensa.

11) Nilce Álvarez. Venta de cosméticos.

12) Nilsa Giménez. Venta de comidas.

13) Mónica González. Venta de comidas.

14) Lorenza Rodríguez. Venta de ropas.

15) Nelly W..Venta de sábanas.

16) Cinthya González. Venta de sábanas.

17) Remigia C.. Despensa.

El crédito que retirán será para comprar mercaderías para sus negocios, dependiendo de que tipo de actividad manejan. Compra de ingredientes para la preparación de comidas, compra de mercaderías para la despensa como azúcar, arroz, fideo, panificados, lácteos, carnes, yerba, etc., además cosméticos, compra de bebidas, compra de ropas, compra de bijouterie, compra de lencerías, compra de productos de limpieza, compra de ropas, compra de sábanas, compra de verduras y compra de materiales para la confección de ropas artesanales. Todas las integrantes asisten a las reuniones semanales y realizan actividades para recaudar fondos para el bien común del grupo.
texts.en:
The group called “Divino Niño Jesús” (Divine Baby Jesus) was established on September 3, 2008 thanks to the publicity done by the advisor in the area, who discussed the Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras (Committee of Enterprising Women) with Ms. Norma E., current general director of the group. She showed an interest in this program and managed to bring together 17 women.

Each one of these women owns a particular business, including the following: 1) Norma E.. Food sales.

2) Librada Gómez. General store.

3) Francisca A.. General store.

4) Liliana M.. Beverage sales.

5) Lucia G.. Traditional clothing.

6) Rosa Samudio. Vegetable sales.

7) Ana D.. Lingerie and costume jewelry sales.

8) Reina S.. Cleaning product sales.

9) Elena González. Beverage sales.

10) Aurora C.. General store.

11) Nilce Álvarez. Cosmetic sales.

12) Nilsa Giménez. Food sales.

13) Mónica González. Food sales.

14) Lorenza Rodríguez. Clothing sales.

15) Nelly W.. Bed sheet sales.

16) Cinthya González. Bed sheet sales.

17) Remigia C.. General store.

The loan they are currently requesting will be used to purchase assorted merchandise depending on their businesses. They will purchase the ingredients needed for food preparation, goods such as sugar, rice, noodles, bread, dairy products, meats, herbs, etc., cosmetics, beverages, clothing, costume jewelry, lingerie, cleaning products, bed sheets, vegetables, and materials needed for making tradictional clothing. All of the members attend weekly meetings and put on fundraisers for the good of the group.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase assorted merchandise

loans.name: Wotunira Group

texts.en:
Robinah is the chair of the Wotunira Loan Group in the Zana district of Kampala. She is a 40-year old married mother of four children, aged 15-22.  She also cares for two adopted orphans.

Robinah has owned an operated a retail electrical supply stall above the old taxi park in Kampala’s city center for 15 years. She sells such things as assortments of wire, switches, power outlets and light appliances.  Her monthly profit averages 150,000 to 200,000 Ush.  

She began using loans many years ago to help develop her business. Her first loan was 50,000 Ush. Her current loan is 1,500,000 Ush, and her revenues have increased commensurately. Robinah will invest the loan proceeds to restock her supplies of copper cabling, arrestors, switches, plugs, power cables, outlets, and related electrical supplies. She imports her stock from Kenya and Dubai, and her smiling face and expertise keep her customers returning.

Robinah’s family depends on her income to pay school fees and contribute to the family’s living costs. With Pearl’s compulsory savings program, Robinah saves 20,000 Ush each week. Someday, she hopes to transition her business into a wholesale distributorship.  This will give her more sales and a consistent revenue stream.  She and her husband hope to be able to afford a plot of land soon so they can construct their own home and see their children educated to the degree level.

loans.use: To restock supplies of copper cabling, arrestors, switches, plugs, power cables, outlets, and related electrical supplies

loans.name: José Andrés

texts.es:
José Andrés tiene 57 años, es casado. Hace 28 años se unió a  Blásida que hoy tiene 45 años y con quien tuvo 4 hijos, tres de los cuales ya son mayores de edad y el último aún vive con ellos.
José se dedica a la faena de ganado, cuya carne vende en la carnicería que funciona en su casa. Al mismo tiempo cuenta con una despensa bien surtida que montó hace más de 25 años. Su esposa le ayuda con el negocio.
Él comenta que es de familia humilde y que junto con su padre anteriormente se dedicaba a la olería (fabricación de ladrillos) y que gracias a su sacrificio logró juntar un pequeño capital para montar la despensa junto con su señora.  Gracias a dicho negocio consiguió estabilidad económica y la posibilidad de sacar adelante a toda su familia y también poder construir su propia vivienda.
De acceder a un crédito, lo estaría invirtiendo en la compra de ganado en pie para engorde que posteriormente lo faenaría para vender la carne en su propia carnicería.
texts.en:
Jose Andres, 57 years old, is married. Twenty eight years ago he joined together with Blásida, now 45, with whom he has four children. Three of them are grown and the youngest still lives with them. Jose works slaughtering cattle, selling the meat in the butcher shop he runs in his home. At the same time he has a well-stocked store that he set up more than 25 years ago. His wife helps with the business. He says that he is from a humble family and with his father he previously worked making bricks. Thanks to their sacrifice he was able to put together a small capital to set up the store along with his wife. Thanks to this business he achieved economic stability and the possibility of moving forward with his entire family, and also being able to build his own home. Having access to credit, he would invest in the purchase of standing cattle to fatten up and later slaughter in order to sell the meat in his own butcher shop.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle for fattening and slaughter

loans.name: Musalam

texts.ru:
Султонова Мусалам Худояровна 1959 года рождения, вдова, имеет 4 иждивенцев. После смерти мужа, чтобы прокормить семью она решила заняться предпринимательской деятельностью. Она занимается торговлей детскими и женскими одеждами. Ассортимент ее товаров  состоит  из женских юбок, брюк, футболок и платьев. Мусалам закупают товар на рынке «Корвон» у оптовиков. Занимается этой деятельностью на рынке "Шохмансур" города Душанбе.
Для  расширения ассортимента, покупка женских пуловер хочет получить займ в сумме 3500 сомони сроком на 6 месяцев.
texts.en:
Musalam Khudoyarovna S. was born in 1959, she is a widow and has four dependents. After her husband's death she decided to start her own business to be able to feed the family. She sells children's and women's clothing. Her inventory consists of women's skirts, pants, t-shirts and dresses. Musalam buys her merchandise on the Korvon market from wholesalers. She has her vendor space on the Shokhmansur market in the city of Dushanbe. To increase her inventory assortment and to buy women's pullovers she decided to apply for a loan in the amount of 3500 somoni (USD$1,025) for a 6 months term.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy women's pullovers

loans.name: Raimkul

texts.en:
K. Raimkul is from the town of Istaravshan. He is 39 years old, married and has four children. Raimkul has always lived in the agricultural region of Istaravshan where he owns a small land and for the last 4 years he has worked as a farmer. He learned this skill from his father. 

On his land he cultivates potato, wheat and other vegetables together with the help of his elder sons. At the same time Raimkul uses his car to provide a taxi service, and also raises cattle. His car requires thorough repairs, which has prompted Ramikul to seek a second loan request through IMON International. This will allow him to purchase spare parts for his car, and earn more money to send his children to university.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing spare parts for his car

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is 30 years old, and she is married with 2 children. She is a LAPO client. She sells snails, fish, and dry pepper. She loves this business because she makes a lot of profits. She needs the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more snails to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more snails to sell

loans.name: Modupe

texts.en: Modupe sells foodstuffs in retail and wholesale. Modupe needs the loan amount of N150,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She is 50 years old and married with 6 children. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Celedonia

texts.en:
Mrs. Celedonia A., 51 years old, is married with 8 children.  She lives in Pagadian City, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines.  Her husband is a government employee.  

The couple has strived hard for the family.  Because of their sewing skills, they decided to venture into the tailoring business, but they did not have access to capital.  With determination and courage, Mrs. A. applied for membership at Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative, and borrowed Php 10,000 through the cooperative.

The small business is going so well that Mrs. A. has decided to expand it.  She is seeking $425 to purchase an additional sewing machine.  Mrs. A. paid her previous loan in a timely fashion, and is a member in good standing of the cooperative.  She has high hopes that God will bless her business.  Mrs. A. and her family hope to set up their own tailoring shop in the city when their profits allow.  In the future, she wants to see all her children finish their studies, and to renovate her family's home.

loans.use: Purchase additional sewing machine

loans.name: Jardin De Rosas Group

texts.es: La costura de ropa, tejido de chompas a mano, el tejido de bolsos y mantas en macramé, son algunos de los negocios de la asociación “Jardín de Rosas” Este grupo trabaja en el centro focal Los Andes, ubicado en la ciudad de El Alto, a la fecha esta formado por catorce miembros. Ahora ellas quieren ampliar sus ventas por lo que necesitan materia prima, tienen la seguridad que sus ventas serán mayores y de este modo generaran mayores recursos.
texts.en:
Some of the "Jardín de Rosas" (Rose Garden) Association's businesses include making hand-sewn clothing, hand-knit sweaters, and hand-woven macramé handbags and blankets. The group currently consists of 14 members and works in the Los Andes Focal Center in the city of El Alto. They want to expand their sales so they need raw materials. They are confident that their sales will grow and generate greater income.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials

loans.name: Mama Penda

texts.fr: mame penda T. est une enseignante qui habite au quartier grand thies;elle est née en 1970 à dakar et est mariée et mère de trois enfants .Parallèlement à métier d'enseignant,elle fait du commerce pour améliorer ses revenus;c'est pour cela qu'elle sollicite un nouveau pret pour renforcer son stock de marchandises.
texts.en:
Mame Penda T. is a teacher who lives in the Grand Thies neighborhood. She was born in 1970 in Dakar and is married and the mother of 3 children. Besides her teaching, she works as a petty trader to increase her income. For that reason, she is requesting a loan so that she can bolster her inventory.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increasing her business inventory

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn C. helps her husband to till their two-hectare (~ 5-acre) rice farm. She is 39 years old and a mother of three children. She and her husband want to expand their business even more. They use the harvest from their farm to feed and clothe their children.

Analyn would like to ask a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizer and chemicals. With the loan that she will borrow from CEVI, she has the chance to improve her harvest.

CEVI helps small business grow. CEVI provides not just credit, but training and insurance coverage, as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys is a trader who sells assorted jewelry. She hawks from one community to the next. She is 28 years old and married with two children. Gladys has insufficient working capital to run her business. With this loan, she plans to inject more working capital into the business to scale it up. She believes the loan will enable her to purchase good quality jewelry in large quantity to upgrade her inventory. She will use part of her profit to finance her kids' education. She is grateful for the assistance.

loans.use: To purchase assorted jewelry

loans.name: Hermenia

texts.en:
Hermenia P. is a 50-year-old woman who has three children with her husband, Quirino P.. Her eldest child is in her second year of college taking Hotel and Restaurant Management; the second to eldest is a third-year high school student; and the youngest is in his sixth grade in elementary. Every year, the education of Hermenia's children incurs bigger financial expenses. Hermenia's business had been very helpful in supporting those expenses and has abled her children to continue their studies.

It has been thirty years that Hermenia is into her business buying and selling fish. Her membership in ASHI and the support of her loving husband and children enabled her to start up the business and have it grow. Despite financial struggles, Hermenia proved her trustworthiness and well-defined values by showing good performance in terms of her repayments, attendance and business.

Recently, Hermenia, her husband and her children decided to apply for a loan in ASHI to enhance her business further and it could profit greatly. The whole family agreed on the idea of buying more variety of fish and to increase the volume of their purchases in order to sell more, cover a wider area of the municipality, and have bigger profits. Aside from intending Hermania's loan for her primary business, they also plan to enhance their hog-fattening business (backyard pig-raising to be sold after four months) for an alternative income during the off-season of fish.

Through the profit Hermenia's hog fattening business would generate, she aspires to purchase a motor fishing boat to be managed by her husband while her profit from buying and selling fish will be intended for her weekly repayments to ASHI, family daily needs, and her children's education.

loans.use: To buy a greater variety of fish to sell and to buy feed for her pig-raising

loans.name: Marieta

texts.en:
Marieta A. is a mother to four children. She is 55 years olds and widowed but she has a business partner Noli, who is her brother. She hails from the busy town of Morong, Rizal province in the Philippines. She has perseverance and determination within her to come out from poverty.

Her desire to pull out her family from the spiral of poverty has driven her to join ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2000. During her membership, she was noted of being one of the most active and with exemplary performance in ASHI.

Her previous loans were invested in her computer shop business. Every time she receives a loan, she put them in the shop as additional capital. Now on her 11th loan, she proposes a loan of 30,000 pesos as additional capital for her computer shop. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for 2 sets of brand new computer as additional units in her shop. She believes that her business will grow since the use of computer shops is in demand by students.

Her dream in life is to expand her business and be able to purchase additional computers, hire labor, and also help her grandchildren with their school fees.

loans.use: To pay for 2 sets of brand new computer as additional units in her shop.

loans.name: Veang

texts.en: T., 31, married to Hung, 34, who run a service of selling meatball and other junk food for years and has given birth to four children all of whom are still young. T. has a skill of beauty salon so she run a service of door to door nail decoration to the surrounding neighbors since 2005 and she earns a good saving. Hung has been spreading his selling very well for he is good at making a delicious sauce with a red color. To catch up his family demand with the fours growing up, Hung wants to increase his income by selling much more meatball in quantity. That's why T. asks for a loan of $ 300 to buy more meatball from the producer for her husband selling. She dreams of having a degree for her children.

loans.use: to buy more meatball from the producer for her husband selling.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort is a 58-year-old married mother of six children. Currently she takes care of just three grandchildren as her own children are independent. Comfort operates a drinking spot where she sells all kinds of drinks such as soft, canned and bottled drinks. She has a wooden kiosk from which she sells the drink. She has been in this business for two years. Comfort is an achiever and her focus is to save enough to sustain her business and provide her grandchildren with good quality education. Without adequate funds Comfort fears it may not be possible to realize her dream.

Comfort is humbly requesting your help to make her dream come true so that she would be better equipped to take care of her family. With her loan, she wants to purchase an increased stock of assorted drinks from the wholesalers to restock her shop.

loans.use: To buy assorted drinks (e.g. Coke, Pepsi) to upgrade her inventory

loans.name: Olimboy

texts.en:
K. Olimboy is a 53 year-old married man. He is a hard-working man who has fought to provide for his family and educate his children, who today are working adults thanks to his example. Olimboy has been running the business of raising and selling cattle. He has 10 years of experience in this field. Since cattle raising and selling is a profitable business, Olimboy has become a very successful businessman in a very short period. Now Olimboy wants to expand his business and buy more cattle. So that he applied for a loan of $ 800 USD. Olimboy thanks all lenders for their support.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing the cattle in order to expand the business and to improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine T., who lives in the village of Barangay Maytubig, Isabela, Negros Occidental, is 29 years old and married to Benny T. who works with her in managing their fish-vending business. They have two young children who are 6 and 8 years old. Her highest aspiration for her family is that her children be able to go to school, earn their college degrees and have all the opportunities to attain a bright future for themselves and their families.

This is what motivated Christine and her husband Benny to engage in their fish-vending business, selling fish to regular customers in their community and even further to the neighboring barangays and sugar plantations. Delivering the fish to their customers was made easy with the aid of their tricycle - a motorcycle with a sidecar attached that can carry the fish containers. They were quite happy with their achievements at that point but then, in 2004, they knew they had the opportunity to expand their business if only they had the necessary capital.

Christine joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to access the new capital she needed to expand the business. As she paid off each loan and borrowed a larger one that she could afford to pay back, Christine and her husband's business improved. Later, with the extra capital, she was able to put up a general store adjacent to her house to cash in on the income opportunity that it offered. The two businesses now earn an average monthly income of PHP 12,000.

For her previous, 11th, loan Christine borrowed PHP 29,500 that was used as additional capital for her business and this loan was fully paid on time without any delays in the weekly installments. For her 12th loan she proposed the same amount of PHP 29,500 to be used for her fish vending and general store businesses. The income from it will be used as savings for her two young children’s future.

In the picture Christine is shown standing outside her store window while her two young children peek out from inside her general store.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her general store and fish-vending businesses

loans.name: Florence Adegoke

texts.en: F. is 55 years old and married with three children. She sells plastic and has been in the business for the past 20 years. She hopes for the loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more plastic to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more plastic to sell

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
Madame Salimata Konaté est une femme  de 44 ans et mère de 2 enfants qui vit avec un de ses enfants dans le quartier Torakabougou de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Après des années d’études à l’école moderne sans réussite, elle décida de s’interesser aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment la préparation et la vente de l’encens. Elle a appris cette activité auprès d’une amie à Bamako (capitale du Mali).
Afin d’obtenir un fond de roulement pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance  Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter les  matières premières entrant dans la préparation de l’encens.  Sa production est vendue à Bougouni dans sa boutique sise au carrefour de lycée, à Bamako et à Sikasso. Elle est très sollicitée pour la qualité de ses produits et sa clientèle est constituée essentiellement de femmes. Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières dans le marché de Bougouni auprès des grossistes.
Elle  espère réaliser  un bénéfice mensuel de 35 000 FCFA qui servira à rembourser les intérêts du prêt et subvenir à ses besoins personnels.
Avec se bénéfice elle envisage agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Ms. Salimata Konaté is a 44-year-old woman and the mother of two children who lives with one of her children in the Torakabougou district of the city of Bougouni (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  After unsuccessful years of modern schooling, she decided to become interested in revenue-generating work, particularly the making and selling of incense.  She learned this business from a friend in Bamako (capital of Mali). To obtain working capital for meeting the needs of her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to buy the raw materials for making incenses.  Her output is sold in Bougouni in her shop near the high school intersection in Bamako and in Sikasso.  She is much sought-after for the quality of her products.  Her customers are made up essentially of women.  She supplies herself with raw materias from wholesalers at the Bougouni marketplace.  She hopes to realize a monthly profit of 35,000 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan interest and to meet her personal needs.  With the profits, she envisions expanding her enterprise.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for making incense

loans.name: María Natividad

texts.es:
La señora María Natividad H.  ya ha tenido un crédito con FVP el cual paga puntual mente y le servio para mejorar su vivienda. Es madre soltera y tiene dos hijos adolescentes bajo su responsabilidad a quienes les quiere dar lo mejor.  
Es por eso que está solicitando un préstamo para empezar la construcción de un cuarto que será para sus niños. 
Doña María Natividad con algunos ahorros pudo comprar el material nada más le está haciendo falta pagar le a la persona que se encargara de realizar la mejor, pero en esta momento no cuanta con el dinero ya que se gasto todo en el material. 
Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito y planea pagarlo con los ingresos que obtiene de su trabajo, en la limpieza de una casa particular. Ya que los gastos de la casa familiares los cubrirá con la pensión alimenticia que recibe para sus hijos.
texts.en:
Sra. María Natividad H. has already had a loan with FVP that was repaid on time and helped to improve her home. She is a single mother with two teenagers for whom she wishes to provide the best.

For this reason, she is requesting a loan to build a room that will be used by her children. Doña María Natividad has savings set aside to purchase the materials, but she lacks the money to pay for labor. She plans to repay the loan using her earnings from her job as a housekeeper at a private home. Her family’s household expenses are covered by the alimony she receives for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay for the construction labor to build a room

loans.name: Soba Soba Sawuya Bongo Group

texts.en: Sawuya B. is a 47-year-old widow with eight children, all of whom are in school, who also cares for three other dependents. For the last year, she has made a living selling charcoal. Sawuya also leads a lending group with six other members, and will use her portion of this loan to buy additional charcoal to sell to her customers. She is a hardworking woman whose dream is to expand her business and improve her family's life.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell to her customers

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en: Patricia makes a living selling traditional beads at retail prices to her customers. These beads are used at marriages and burial and naming ceremonies. Nigerians love traditional beads because they are an important part of their cultural heritage. Patricia is married, has three children and is 45 years old. She has been in her line of work for a long time and has applied for a loan for 100,000 NGN to buy more traditional beads to sell. She is a focused, hard-working woman who puts in long hours trying to keep her business sustainable. She is a LAPO client because of our commitment to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Patricia extends her sincerest thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more traditional beads to sell to her customers

loans.name: Betty's Group

texts.en:
Betty A. is from the village of San Rafael. She is 49 years old. Betty is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is A.'s Group.

Betty is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Betty owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Betty has been engaged in her business for over 21 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Betty joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Betty has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Betty is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Betty from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of the borrower's children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Maintaining his coconut farm

loans.name: Elsa's Group

texts.en: Elsa P. is from the village of Saranay, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 46 years old and is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Elsa is married and has two school-aged children. She owns and operates a business selling personal-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Elsa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be her fourth from ASKI. Elsa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines.
